Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Gaining Fuctional Insights on Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors Through Structural Studies

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
My work focused on gaining a better understanding of how a particular type of ion channel called the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (nAChR) functions.  These channels are essential for cognition and play a role in numerous neurological diseases and disorders such as Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, schizophrenia, and epilepsy. Additionally, nAChRs play a role in addiction since they bind the nicotine that enters the body through tobacco use. Furthermore, nAChRs are similar to several other types of ion channels found in the body.  Therefore, what we learn about the nAChR can be helpful in the treatment of multiple neurological diseases in addition to shedding light on how other ion channels in our bodies function.

I was trained in molecular biology techniques at the Institute of Biophysics, a part of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. The lab I worked in, that of Zhi-Jie Liu, had superb resources and well-trained scientists that were able to guide me in my project; it was an ideal place to perform my proposed research. The collaboration between my lab in the United States and the Institute of Biophysics in China is ongoing. We have continued to work together towards determining the three-dimensional structure of the human nAChRs so that we may gain a better understanding of their function. Ultimately, this work may aid in the development of new drugs that combat neurological diseases.
